title.native: アミテージ・ザ・サード

description:
The year is 2046. Detective Ross Sylibus is transferred to Mars when a country singer on his flight is murdered. Making matters more complicated is that the singer is a "Third"—a robot that looks and feels like a human. Sylibus is partnered with Armitage—a beautiful female cop with a bad attitude. As they investigate the murder of the singer and other women on Mars, they uncover a conspiracy that can have them both killed by the Martian government.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Cyborg
tags.description: Prominently features a human character whose physiological functions are aided or enhanced by artificial means.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Politics

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

name.native: ケリー・マッキャノン

node.description: She works for Group Komadori. Her debut animation was "Ginga Hyouryu BYFAM".

[Website](http://www.konaka.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yamaki_nyx)

Chiaki J. Konaka is a Japanese writer and scenarist best known for shows such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Digimon Tamers](https://anilist.co/anime/874/) and [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). He is also known to be the creator of Ultraman Gaia, as cited by Tsuburaya Productions.

Konaka's serious works generally have a dark, psychological tone. As a Cthulhu Mythos writer, he tends to add Lovecraftian elements to his works.

"Chiaki J. Konaka" is a very unusual name, as Japanese names typically do not include middle names. Konaka states that the "J." evokes the "Christian" name "John", due to him being born to parents who were members of the Anglican Church, but he does not identify as Christian. He began using the "J." at the age of 12, when he began making 8 mm films; he patterned the style after Western names such as "Charles M. Schulz".

He has cited [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) as his favorite screenwriting project.

[Website](http://www.konaka.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yamaki_nyx)

Chiaki J. Konaka is a Japanese writer and scenarist best known for shows such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Digimon Tamers](https://anilist.co/anime/874/) and [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). He is also known to be the creator of Ultraman Gaia, as cited by Tsuburaya Productions.

Konaka's serious works generally have a dark, psychological tone. As a Cthulhu Mythos writer, he tends to add Lovecraftian elements to his works.

"Chiaki J. Konaka" is a very unusual name, as Japanese names typically do not include middle names. Konaka states that the "J." evokes the "Christian" name "John", due to him being born to parents who were members of the Anglican Church, but he does not identify as Christian. He began using the "J." at the age of 12, when he began making 8 mm films; he patterned the style after Western names such as "Charles M. Schulz".

He has cited [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) as his favorite screenwriting project.

Affiliated with [Studio Silver](https://anilist.co/studio/6240/). Older brother of [You Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102998/).

He is known for having reached great expertise in many techniques from realistic animation to digital compositing. This gives him the ability to have full control over his works, often being responsible for the key frames, in-betweens, finishing, photography and backgrounds of the scenes he is in charge of.

His skilled use of coloring and compositing, together with the realistic depiction of movement make his works to be often mistaken for computer generated animation.

**Notable works outside anime:**
~!
- Ghost in the Shell (Video Game, 1997) (OP Key Animation)
- Tales of Phantasia (Video Game, 1998) (Cutscene Director, Animation Director, Key Animation)
- Valkyrie Profile Series (Video Game, 1999-2008) (Character Design, Art Design) 
- Kafu ~Kono Shirabe ga Kimi ni Todokimasu You ni~ (Visual Novel, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography, CG Animation)
- Sakura Wars 3: Paris is Burning? (Video Game, 2001) (OP Key Animation, In-Between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Akiiro Renka (Visual Novel, 2005) (OP Director, Animation Character Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography)
- Muv-Luv Alternative (Visual Novel, 2006) (Cutscene Mecha Design, Key Animation, In-between Animation, Background Art, Digital Paint, Photography) !~

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/110221339) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/815589398720847872)

He joined studio Bebow in 1982, where he was referred to by [Masayuki Yagi](https://anilist.co/staff/143406/), a senior of his at Engaru High School. [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) and Bebow’s founder [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/) were also graduates of the same school - the latter whom he would study under after joining the studio. There he made his debut as a key animator on [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/) in the following year.

He left Bebow in the mid ‘80s and joined Pack, a small studio established by [Hiroyuki Kitazume](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/). During this time he was a follower of Kitazume’s, who has said that Onda was the one capable of replicating his drawing’s the best out of the people who worked at studio Pack. After that he joined [Atelier Giga](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/) and worked there until becoming a freelancer.

His drawings feature western-influenced delicate and sharp linework with an excellent grasp on three-dimensionality. His character art in particular is highly praised both inside and outside of the industry, which he gets to brandish whenever he works as an animation supervisor. He has stated that he prefers character design and supervision work over working as an animator himself.

In 2003, he took part as a key animator on [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/)'s animated segment in Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" directed by [Kazuto Nakazawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101474/). He is also a huge fan of shoujo manga since a young age due to his older sister.

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/110221339) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/815589398720847872)

He joined studio Bebow in 1982, where he was referred to by [Masayuki Yagi](https://anilist.co/staff/143406/), a senior of his at Engaru High School. [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) and Bebow’s founder [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/) were also graduates of the same school - the latter whom he would study under after joining the studio. There he made his debut as a key animator on [Seisenshi Dunbine](https://anilist.co/anime/929/) in the following year.

He left Bebow in the mid ‘80s and joined Pack, a small studio established by [Hiroyuki Kitazume](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/). During this time he was a follower of Kitazume’s, who has said that Onda was the one capable of replicating his drawing’s the best out of the people who worked at studio Pack. After that he joined [Atelier Giga](https://anilist.co/staff/106775/) and worked there until becoming a freelancer.

His drawings feature western-influenced delicate and sharp linework with an excellent grasp on three-dimensionality. His character art in particular is highly praised both inside and outside of the industry, which he gets to brandish whenever he works as an animation supervisor. He has stated that he prefers character design and supervision work over working as an animator himself.

In 2003, he took part as a key animator on [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/)'s animated segment in Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" directed by [Kazuto Nakazawa](https://anilist.co/staff/101474/). He is also a huge fan of shoujo manga since a young age due to his older sister.

[Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=naoyuki_konno)

__Naoyuki Konno__ is a Japanese animator and director. He is particularly known for his work on several adaptations of [Shoutarou Ishinomori's](https://anilist.co/staff/97478/Shoutarou-Ishinomori) works as well as his animation style, being renowned as one of the Kanada-school animators.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/真木太郎)

Tarou Maki is a producer. He graduated from the Department of Law at Waseda University in 1977 and joined Pioneer. In 1997 he founded production studio [Genco](https://anilist.co/studio/79/) and serves today still as its president.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/北爪宏幸)

His representative works include [Mobile Suit Gundam ZZ](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Char's Counterattack](https://anilist.co/anime/87/) and [Moldiver](https://anilist.co/anime/571/).

Retired from the anime industry in the early 2000s and has since worked on manga.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/竹内敦志)

Affiliated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/). Takeuchi is a renown mechanical designer and anime director, having worked on such high profile projects as [The Sky Crawlers](https://anilist.co/anime/3089/) and [Ghost in the Shell](Ghost in the Shell).

He also took part in the production of Star Wars: The Clone Wars.

[Website](http://qbo.sakura.ne.jp/masahiko/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/macha_mkun) | [Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/people/39493978@N08/)

In recent years he has also been working as still photographer.

Director who started off as an animator. Still animates on occasions.

Married to [Sayo Aoi](https://anilist.co/staff/118784/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/新井浩一)

One of the founders of [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/corporate_x) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/越智博之)

Specializes in mechanical animation. Currently affiliated with [Zero-G](https://anilist.co/studio/6117/).

Attended an art school before joining studio Bevore. Long-time friend of [Naoyuki Onda](https://anilist.co/staff/102427/)'s, who worked with him at the studio. Participated on numerous of AIC's projects in the late '80s and early '90s.

Debuted as a director with [Armitage](https://anilist.co/anime/1079/) in 1995.
